questions.text: During an outbreak investigation in Kerala, India, several patients presented with fever and encephalitis. The outbreak is linked to contact with infected pigs, and fruit bats are abundant in the area. Laboratory analysis of patient samples reveals a paramyxovirus. The mortality rate is approximately 70%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Key Facts (NIPAH)
  • N - Nervous system affected
  • I - Infection mortality 60-70%
  • P - Pigs are amplifiers
  • A - Animal-to-human transmission
  • H - History of the outbreak in Kerala 2018

Transmission Cycle
  • Vector: Fruit bats (natural reservoir)
  • Intermediate host: Pigs (amplifiers)
  • Human infection: Through contaminated food/water
  • Patient secretions can spread disease

Clinical Features
  • Encephalitis (primary manifestation)
  • Fever
  • High mortality rate (60-70%)
  • Neurological symptoms

Diagnosis
  • RT-PCR is the primary diagnostic test
  • Sample: CSF or brain tissue
  • Serology can be supportive

Prevention
  • Avoid contact with infected animals
  • Proper handling of infected pig carcasses
  • Avoid consuming contaminated fruits
  • Protection from fruit bat secretions

questions.text: A 30 y/o farmer from Central Asia presents with high fever, muscle pain, and significant bleeding from his gums and nose. He mentions being bitten by a tick while working on his farm. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Bunyaviridae
  • Bunyaviridae is a large family of over 300 arbovirus species, mostly spread by mosquitoes and ticks.
  • Structure: Virions are spherical, enveloped, and are about 100 nm in size. They have a segmented, single-stranded RNA genome.
  • Key Genera: Four genera are medically significant—Bunyavirus, Phlebovirus, Nairovirus, and Hantavirus. Hantaviruses are rodent-borne rather than transmitted by arthropods.

Name

Features

Transmission

Genus Bunyavirus
  • Encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, and fever.
  • California encephalitis viruses are endemic to the USA.
  • Oropouche virus causes fever with aseptic meningitis in Brazil.

California encephalitis virus - Mosquito

Oropouche virus - Midges

Genus Phlebovirus

Causes sandfly fever (Pappataci fever) in Central Asia and Rift Valley fever in Africa.

Fever and myalgia

Sandfly fever - Phlebotomus papatasii sandflies

Rift Valley fever - Mosquitoes (Option B ruled out)

Genus Nairovirus (Option C)

Nairobi sheep disease virus and Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF).

CCHF - Hyalomma ticks

Genus Hantavirus

Causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS).

Hantaan virus: Severe HFRS in Asia and Russia. (Option D ruled out)

Seoul virus: Worldwide mild disease

Puumala virus: Mild nephropathia in Europe.

Sin Nombre virus: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. (Option A ruled out)

Rodents

questions.text: A 45-year-old male returns from South America and presents to the ED with severe abdominal pain, jaundice, and bleeding manifestations. O/E his liver is enlarged, and lab tests show elevated liver enzymes. Despite receiving medical care, he did not survive. An autopsy shows the presence of intranuclear Torre bodies in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis, and which vaccine could have prevented it?

A 26-y/o patient presents with fever, headache, muscle and joint pains, and maculopapular rashes over the chest and upper limbs for five days. The patient reports lymphadenopathy, retro-orbital pain, and loss of appetite. Lab results show haemoglobin at 10 g/dL, WBC count of 10,000 cells/mm³, platelet count of 15,000 cells/mm³, and prolonged bleeding time with normal clotting time. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman receives a positive HIV screening test result. To confirm the diagnosis, the healthcare provider decides to use a supplemental test for validation due to its high specificity in detecting individual antibodies against various HIV antigens. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis in this case?

A 30 y/o man presents to the clinic with flu-like symptoms 12 days after potential exposure to HIV. The clinician suspects acute HIV infection and orders a diagnostic test. Which test would be most appropriate to confirm the infection at this early stage and provide insights into the viral load?
Which of the following findings would be most indicative of HTLV-1-associated adult T-cell leukaemia (ATL)?

options.label: A
options.text: High levels of interleukin-2 receptors in peripheral blood

options.label: B
options.text: Detection of p24 antigen in serum

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of CD4+ T cells in the peripheral blood

options.label: D
options.text: Detection of GLUT1 on the surface of leukemic cells

questions.correct_answer: A. High levels of interleukin-2 receptors in peripheral blood

questions.text: A 68 y/o man with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with fever, shortness of breath, and ground-glass peripheral opacities on chest imaging as shown in image below. Which mechanism most likely explains the severe respiratory symptoms he is experiencing?

options.label: D
options.text: Cytokine storm causing alveolar and endothelial damage

questions.correct_answer: D. Cytokine storm causing alveolar and endothelial damage
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis of COVID-19

Host Cell Entry
  • Binding: Spike glycoprotein (S) attaches to angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE-2) receptors on lung type II alveolar cells.
  • Cleavage: Host proteases (e.g., TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein, facilitating viral entry via the endosomal pathway.

Initial Inflammatory Response
  • Influenza-like Illness (ILI): Infection of the pharyngeal epithelium initiates ILI.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
  • Damage to Alveolar Cells: Impaired type II alveolar cells decrease pulmonary surfactant, causing alveolar collapse and fluid retention. (Option B ruled out)
  • Cytokine Storm: Increased immune cytokine release leads to:
    • Tissue damage and necrosis.
    • Impaired gas exchange and hypoxia.
    • Endothelial damage and microvascular thrombosis.
    • Pulmonary oedema and ground-glass opacities on imaging.
    • Fibrosis and respiratory failure.

Multiorgan Failure
  • Elevated cytokines may harm other organs, resulting in sepsis, septic shock, and acute kidney/cardiac injury.

Risk Factors for Severe Disease
  • Demographics: Age > 60 years.
  • Comorbidities: Diabetes, hypertension, COPD, CKD and cancer.

questions.text: A patient comes to the clinic with symptoms of a viral infection. The physician is reviewing potential viruses based on their classification into myxovirus families. Which of the following viruses is NOT a member of the Paramyxoviridae family?
questions.explanation:
Properties

Orthomyxoviridae

Paramyxoviridae

Size

80-120 nm

100-300 nm

Shape

Spherical; Rarely filamentous

Pleomorphic

Nucleic acid

Negative sense ssRNA, Segmented; eight pieces

Negative sense ssRNA Unsegmented; single piece

Genetic recombination

Seen

Not seen

Antigenic variation

Seen

Not seen

Site for RNA Replication

Nucleus

Cytoplasm

Important human pathogens

Influenza virus

Parainfluenza virus, Mumps virus Respiratory syncytial virus Measles virus, Metapneumovirus

Antigens: Hemagglutinin (HA) and Neuraminidase (NA)

Both HA and NA spikes are present, So hemagglutination is reversible (Elution seen)

HA spike present in Parainfluenza, Mumps, Measles,

NA spike present in Parainfluenza, Mumps

Inclusion body: Intracytoplasmic (only for measles, it is both intracytoplasmic and intranuclear)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the emergency department with complaints of high fever, severe headache, and muscle aches that started 24 hours ago. He mentions he has been feeling increasingly fatigued and has developed a dry cough. Which of the following statements about the virus causing his symptoms is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Amantadine acts against both A and B strains of the virus whereas Oseltamivir acts against strain A only.

options.label: B
options.text: The incubation period for the virus is 7 to 14 days.

options.label: C
options.text: The immune response mainly involves antibodies against the hemagglutinin protein.

options.label: D
options.text: Once infected, individuals develop lifelong immunity against all strains of the virus.

questions.correct_answer: C. The immune response mainly involves antibodies against the hemagglutinin protein.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes antigenic drift and antigenic shift in influenza viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Drift causes pandemics; shift causes minor epidemics.

options.label: B
options.text: Drift involves minor mutations; shift involves genetic reassortment.

options.label: C
options.text: Shift occurs in Influenza A and B; drift occurs only in Influenza A.

options.label: D
options.text: Drift produces a new strain; shift evades immune recognition.

questions.correct_answer: B. Drift involves minor mutations; shift involves genetic reassortment.
questions.explanation:
Antigenic Drift

Antigenic Shift
  • Minor change due to point mutations in HA/NA genes, altering amino acid sequences and helping the virus partially evade immune recognition. (Option D)
  • Requires two or more mutations for significant impact.
  • Occurs in both influenza A and B viruses. (Option C)
  • Leads to outbreaks and minor epidemics, occurring every 2–3 years. (Option A)
  • An abrupt, major change in HA/NA genes due to genetic reassortment between influenza viruses infecting the same host.
  • Produces a new virus strain, making prior antibodies ineffective. (Option D)
  • Occurs only in influenza A virus. (Option C)
  • Causes pandemics and major epidemics, with shifts happening every 10–20 years (e.g., the H1N1 pandemic of 2009). (Option A)

questions.text: A 3-year-old unvaccinated child presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash that began on the face and has spread to the trunk and limbs. Oral examination reveals small, white lesions on the buccal mucosa. Which complication is most likely to develop in the acute phase of this illness?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Duration

Symptoms

Incubation Period

10 days (up to 21 days)

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with bilateral painful swelling in the region of his parotid glands that began 2 days ago. His mother notes that the pain worsens when he drinks orange juice. He had a fever of 101.2°F (38.4°C) before the swelling appeared. The patient's vaccination status is unknown. During examination, bilateral parotid enlargement is noted. Which of the following is the most specific diagnostic test to confirm the suspected infection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis Methods

RT-PCR
  • Buccal swab
  • Most specific test
  • Collect within first 3 days

Antigen
  • ELISA method
  • Used for rapid screening

Clinical Features
  • Bilateral parotitis
  • Pain increases with citrus juices
  • Fever and malaise

Culture

Only in cell lines

Vaccine Details- MMR

Recommended Strain- Mumps

Jeryl Lynn Strain

Measles Strain

Edmonston/Zagreb

Rubella Strain

RA 27/3

Type

MMR-V (with varicella)

questions.text: During an outbreak investigation in a labor colony, health officials are tracking a viral infection. The causative virus has these characteristics: exclusively human reservoir, fecal-oral transmission, and three distinct serotypes. The outbreak is showing these features: predominantly affects unvaccinated children, begins with fever and headache, and in some cases progresses to acute flaccid paralysis. The investigation team is discussing viral characteristics. Which of the following statements about this virus is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Virus can be isolated from feces for up to 6 weeks after symptom onset

options.label: C
options.text: Type 1 is the least common cause of epidemics

options.label: D
options.text: Virus shedding begins 2 days before symptom onset

questions.correct_answer: C. Type 1 is the least common cause of epidemics
questions.explanation:
Poliovirus

Types and Strains
  • Type 1 (Brunhilde, Mahoney): Most common, causes epidemics
  • Type 2 (Lansing, MEF1): Endemic infections (Option B)
  • Type 3 (Leon, Saukett): Can cause epidemics

Viral Antigens
  • D antigen: Found in whole virion, type-specific, protective
  • C antigen: Found in empty virus, not protective
  • No common group antigen
  • Heat converts D to C antigen (56°C)

Transmission Factors
  • Route: Primarily fecal-oral
  • Source: Human feces, throat secretions
  • Reservoir: Only humans
  • Environmental survival: 6 months in sewage
  • Resistant to: pH 3, ether, detergents

Time Course
  • Incubation: Range 4-28 days (average 10)
  • Communicable period: -2 to +5 days from symptoms
  • Fecal shedding: Up to 6 weeks (Option A)
  • Initial symptoms: 1-5 days
  • Asymptomatic period: 2-3 days
  • Major illness onset: 3-4 days after minor illness

Clinical-Epidemiological Aspects
  • Subclinical:Clinical = 1000:1 or 100:1
  • Risk enhancers: Pregnancy, tonsillectomy, injections
  • Cross-immunity: Between 1&2, 2&3; minimal 1&3
  • Peak season: Late winter and early spring
  • No carrier state exists

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure and characteristics of the Rabies virus?

options.label: A
options.text: Spherical structure and is best visualized by light microscopy.

options.label: B
options.text: Single-stranded RNA genome and is best visualized using electron microscopy.

options.label: C
options.text: Has a hexagonal structure, observed under a compound microscope.

options.label: D
options.text: There are three types of antigens in Rabies

questions.correct_answer: B. Single-stranded RNA genome and is best visualized using electron microscopy.
questions.explanation:
Glycoprotein G

Nucleoprotein

Present in envelope

Associated with viral RNA

Species-specific

Group specific

Binds to acetylcholine receptor

No role in binding and inducing antibody

Plays a role in vaccination

Cross-reacts with other rabies-related viruses
